I have a single server in a vpg, with some rather large drives. The vpg uses a 30 day journal history size.  For this server, we use shadowcopies on  many of the drives. I have added a new drive to the server to relocate our existing shadowcopy locations to (so they are not on the same drive as the data). I went to go and change this new drive so the vpg does a No Sync on it, and am presented with the following:

When changing the volume sync settings from Continuous Sync or Initial Sync Only to No Sync, all the previous checkpoints of this vpg will be removed and cannot be recovered. New checkpoints will be created from this point forward.

This can't really be a thing, that adding a new drive and excluding it from syncing would cause us to lose 30 days of history? Is there any way around this? This seems lame to no be able to do this without losing 30 days of checkpoints!

How can we ignore or bypass this alert so the status of vpg will go back to green?

We understand the issue is related to having multiple volumes or particular the d drive being used and conflicting on Azure.

The Microsoft default SAN policy might cause VM 'Dublin (Dynamics GP)' (VPG 'Test SQL to Azure') volumes to become offline upon recovery.

The issue is these SQL servers have two NICs and three IPs, and VCD Guest Customizations seems to only be able to handle one IP per NIC.

The behavior we see is the two IPs that are on the fist NIC get placed on two seperate NICs during a failover, and the third IP (the SQL heartbeat IP) doesn't get applied at all.  What ends up happening is that without the SQL heartbeat, both servers start trying to assign the same IPs since their trying to failover for each other, creating IP conflicts.

I was wondering if adding a third NIC on the production VMs for those SQL servers, but leaving it unbound without an IP in Windows would be a valid work around for this issue? I am unable to upgrade from 10.0.41 to 10.0.50 due to this issue. I followed the steps below and still unsuccesful.

Reference: https://help.zerto.com/bundle/RN.HTML.10.0_U5/page/release_notes_for_zerto_10_0_update_5.html

Workaround: To resolve this issue and re-initiate the upgrade, follow these steps:

    Make sure that Encryption Detection is enabled. 
    In theZerto User Interface, click the menu button in the top right of the header and select Site Settings. Select the Encryption Detection tab. Make sure that the Encryption Analyzer checkbox under Encryption Detection is selected. 
    Note: If you wish to disable Encryption Detection, unselect the Encryption Analyzer checkbox only after completing the next steps described in this workaround or after the upgrade is complete.

    Identify Suspected Protection Groups:

    Run the GET API to obtain a list of all suspected VPGs (Virtual Protection Groups) with volumes flagged for potential encryption issues:
    GET /v1/encryptio

Hello Team, 
Can you please help disabling the weak cipher 3DES on our (Linux) ZVMs . 

I have a procedure I just want to make sure if this is the correct way. 

1.Edit the SSL/TLS configuration file. This is often found in /etc/ssl/ or /etc/httpd/ depending on your setup.

2. Disable 3DES Weak Cipher by modify the configuration by adding !3DES to configuration file:
For example:
SSLProtocol all -SSLv2 -SSLv3 -TLSv1 -TLSv1.1
 SSLCipherSuite HIGH:!aNULL:!MD5:!3DES
This configuration disables SSLv2, SSLv3, TLSv1, and TLSv1.1, and removes the 3DES cipher which is associated with the SWEET32 vulnerability.

3.Restart the Service after making these changes.
sudo systemctl restart httpd

By restarting httpd service will it affect the VPGs and replications ? 

Thank You
